Cultivation: Grow in well-drained, acidic soil in full sun. See Hardy heathers for further advice
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to honey fungus (rarely) and other fungal diseases
EntityDescription: A hardy, evergreen shrub with a compact, bushy habit approximately 21-25cm tall with a spread to 31-45cm.  It has dark green foliage and spikes of double white flowers in summer through to autumn.
GenusDescription: Calluna are low-growing or dwarf evergreen shrubs with stems clothed in tiny overlapping leaves, and terminal, spike-like racemes of small, 4-petalled flowers with coloured calyces
PestResistance: Generally pest-free
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
Pruning: Pruning group 10

Cultivation: Plant bulbs in autumn, 15cm deep, in moist but well-drained soil enriched with leaf mould or well-rotted organic matter, in a sheltered position, with the base of the plant in shade, for example from ground-cover plants, and the rest of the plant in full sun; for more advice, see growing lilies in containers
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to lily disease, other fungal diseases, and virus diseases; for more advice, see lily diseases
EntityDescription: A deciduous, bulbous, herbaceous perennial to around 60cm, with strap-like dark green leaves and small, fragrant, downward-facing, recurved orange flowers appearing earlier than other varieties from May through to the summer
GenusDescription: Lilium are bulbous perennials with erect stems bearing whorled or spirally arranged leaves and terminal racemes or umbels of bowl-shaped, trumpet-shaped, funnel-shaped or turks cap shaped flowers, often fragrant, and white, yellow, orange or red
PestResistance: May be susceptible to lily beetle, aphids, slugs, snails, Thrips, leatherjackets, and wireworms, and to damage by rabbits and voles; plants in containers may be affected by vine weevil
Propagation: Propagate by division: separate offsets after the leaves have died down
Pruning: No pruning required, but deadheading will improve their appearance

Cultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, well-drained soil, enriched with organic matter and general purpose fertiliser, in full sun. Pinch out growing tips to encourage bushy plants and stake. Water freely in dry periods. Lift and store tubers in autumn to replant or use as a source of cuttings in spring
DiseaseResistance: Powdery mildews can be damaging in dry conditions. In wet weather grey moulds and other fungal rots can be a problem. Fungal rots can also damage stored tubers. A virus may cause stunting, leaf markings and distortion
EntityDescription: Grows to 90cm in height, with white, double flowers 12cm in width, with rather broad, overlapping florets
GenusDescription: Dahlia are tuberous rooted perennials with pinnately divided leaves and showy flowerheads, double in many cultivars, in summer and autumn
HortGroupDescription: Decorative dahlias have fully double flowerheads with flat or slightly incurved florets
PestResistance: Aphids, leaf miners, glasshouse red spider mite and slugs are common pests. Earwigs sometimes damage blooms. Capsid bug and caterpillars are occasional pests
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings taken in spring from shoots from stored tubers, or divide the tubers ensuring each division has a viable bud
Pruning: Deadhead to prolong flowering. Cut back to near ground level in the autumn, before lifting and storing for the winter

Cultivation: Will grow well in soils that are moderately fertile and moist but well-drained preferably in full sun but will tolerate some shade. Once the plant is established it will require less watering.
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to honey fungus (rarely), powdery mildews, verticillium wilt and foot and root rots
EntityDescription: An upright perennial grown as an annual, with lance-shaped silvery green foliage, hairy on the reverse, and slender racemes of small white lipped flowers in summer and autumn.
GenusDescription: Salvia can be annuals, biennials, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, or shrubs. They have paired, simple or pinnately lobed, often aromatic leaves and 2-lipped flowers in whorls, forming simple or branched spikes or racemes
PestResistance: Generally pest-free
Propagation: Propagate by division in spring and by semi-ripe cuttings in summer
Pruning: Cut back flower spikes to prolong flowering

AutoCompleteField: Lilium pyrenaicum (IXc/d)|Pyrenean lily|yellow Turk's cap lily
Cultivation: Plant bulbs in autumn, 15cm deep, in moist but well-drained soil enriched with leaf mould or well-rotted organic matter, in a sheltered position, with the base of the plant in shade, for example from ground-cover plants, and the rest of the plant in full sun; for more advice, see growing lilies in containers
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to lily disease, other fungal diseases, and virus diseases; for more advice, see lily diseases
EntityDescription: A deciduous, bulbous perennial, one of few lillies which has become naturalised in the UK and can be seen growing in the hedgrows in North Devon and the Lake District.  It has strap-like dark green leaves and nodding, yellow flowers with dark red speckles.  Flowers are downward and recurved, appearing early in the season, sometimes at the end of May
GenusDescription: Lilium are bulbous perennials with erect stems bearing whorled or spirally arranged leaves and terminal racemes or umbels of bowl-shaped, trumpet-shaped, funnel-shaped or turks cap shaped flowers, often fragrant, and white, yellow, orange or red
PestResistance: May be susceptible to lily beetle, aphids, slugs, snails, Thrips, leatherjackets, and wireworms, and to damage by rabbits and voles; plants in containers may be affected by vine weevil
Propagation: Propagate by division: separate offsets after the leaves have died down
Pruning: No pruning required, but deadheading will improve their appearance

Cultivation: Grow in well-drained, fertile, neutral to slightly acid loam in full sun
DiseaseResistance: May be subject to iris rhizome rot, a leaf spot and a virus
EntityDescription: 'Sherbet Lemon' is a vigorous perennial with yellowish-green leaves and stems to 45cm, bearing up to 4 flowers, the standards and falls very pale yellow with greenish-yellow veining, the falls with an orange beard
GenusDescription: Iris may be rhizomatous or bulbous perennials, with narrow leaves and erect stems bearing flowers with 3 large spreading or pendent fall petals, alternating with 3 erect, often smaller, standard petals, in late winter, spring or early summer
HortGroupDescription: Intermediate Bearded irises are deciduous rhizomatous perennials, growing between 40 and 70cm tall, with sword-shaped light glaucous green leaves and erect stems bearing flowers 10-13cm across, bearded on the falls, in late spring and early summer
PestResistance: May be attacked by slugs, snails and thrips
Propagation: Propagate by division of rhizomes from midsummer to early autumn
Pruning: Remove any dying foliage in autumn, old flower stems can be cut down after flowering
Toxicity: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling

Cultivation: Grow in a cold frame in a loam-based potting compost and move into a warm glasshouse in early autumn. Provide bright filtered light with good ventilation and a minimum temperature of 10°C. During the growing season water moderately and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser weekly
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to glasshouse grey mould, powdery mildews and chrysanthemum white rust
EntityDescription: grows to 1.2m, and has sprays of bright yellow flowers in autumn
GenusDescription: Chrysanthemum are erect woody-based perennials with aromatic, pinnately lobed leaves and flowerheads of diverse form, from late summer to late autumn
HortGroupDescription: Reflexed Indoor Spray chrysanthemums have branched stems bearing several fully double flowerheads with recurved florets
PestResistance: May be susceptible to leaf and bud eelworms, aphids, glasshouse whitefly, glasshouse red spider mite and capsid bug
Propagation: Propagate by rooting softwood cuttings in loam-less potting compost at 16°C
Pruning: Pinch out growing tips and disbud as required

Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, humus rich soil, in a lightly shaded spot. Pink flower colours are best maintained by growing in slightly alkaline soil, though this cultivar has some resistance to blueing in mildly acidic soils. Mulch annually in spring. See shrubby hydrangea cultivation for more detailed advice
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to a leaf spot, powdery mildews, grey moulds (Botrytis) and honey fungus (rarely)
EntityDescription: A deciduous shrub to 1.2m high with broadly oval, toothed, glossy green leaves. Dome-shaped clusters of flowers are produced from mid to late summer; in the right soil these develop from bright green through deep pink to near red as the season progresses
GenusDescription: Hydrangea can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs, or self-clinging climbers, with flowers in clusters usually comprising both small fertile and more showy sterile flowers; often good autumn colour
HortGroupDescription: Hortensia hydrangeas (also known as mopheads) are compact bushy deciduous shrubs with broadly ovate leaves and rounded flower clusters composed almost entirely of showy sterile flowers
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, capsid bug, red spider mite, stem and bulb eelworm, vine weevil and scale insects
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer, or by hardwood cuttings in winter
Pruning: See pruning group 4 (hydrangeas)
Toxicity: Skin allergen.  Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling

Cultivation: Grow in fertile, moist but well-drained soils in full sun or partial shade. Young plants are best left undisturbed to form clumps; use a dry mulch for the first two winters. See Alstroemeria cultivation
DiseaseResistance: Generally disease-free but may be susceptible to a virus
EntityDescription: Clump-forming perennial about 90cm tall, with lance-shaped mid-green leaves, and bearing large clusters of greenish-white flowers, the outer petals with a central deep purple blotch, the inner ones with a brown-flecked yellow flush in the throat
GenusDescription: Alstroemeria are fleshy rooted herbaceous perennials forming spreading clumps of erect stems bearing narrowly lance-shaped leaves, with umbels of showy funnel-shaped flowers in summer
PestResistance: May be susceptible to slugs
Propagation: Propagate by division in autumn or very early spring
Pruning: Pull up spent flowered stems, leaving tubers in ground
Toxicity: Contact with foliage may cause skin allergies. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling

Cultivation: Grow outdoors in moist but well-drained soil in full sun.  Protect from cold drying winds.  Grow under glass in loam-based compost in full light
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to powdery mildews, leafspot and honey fungus (rarely)
EntityDescription: A slow-growing medium-sized evergreen shrub of dense, rounded habit. Leaves obovate, dark green with creamy-white margins. Small, sweetly-scented white flowers in late spring and early summer turn yellow with age
GenusDescription: Pittosporum are evergreen shrubs or trees with simple, leathery leaves and small, often fragrant, 5-petalled flowers, followed by spherical, woody fruits splitting to reveal seeds embedded in sticky pulp
PestResistance: May be susceptible to glasshouse red spider mite, aphids, cushion scale and pittosporum sucker
Propagation: Propagate by seed or semi-hardwood cuttings
Pruning: Pruning group 1

Cultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in full sun. Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter or early spring, and for best flowering apply a general rose or shrub fertiliser in early spring and again in early summer. See rose cultivation
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to rose black spot, rose rust, replant disease, rose dieback, and rose powdery mildew. May also be susceptible to disorders rose blindness and flower balling and sometimes honey fungus
EntityDescription: Spreading rose about 1m tall and 2m wide, with healthy, semi-glossy mid-green leaves. Small clusters of lightly scented, semi-double, crimson-red blooms open to show golden-yellow stamens, with profuse flowering repeatedly through summer and autumn
GenusDescription: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
HortGroupDescription: Ground Cover roses are low, spreading shrubs with small, glossy leaves and clusters of single or double, occasionally slightly fragrant, flowers in summer, usually repeat-flowering
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly, rose slugworm sawfly and rose leaf-rolling sawfly. Deer and rabbits can cause damage
Propagation: Propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn, softwood cuttings (under glass) in spring or summer or by chip budding in summer
Pruning: See pruning group 19 (groundcover roses)

Cultivation: Grow in moisture-retentive, humus-rich, well-drained soil in sun or light dappled shade; will grow in a wide range of soils but prefers acidic or neutral soil
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to fireblight, apple canker, silver leaf and honey fungus
EntityDescription: A slow-growing tree, up to 6m high, narrowly-conical when mature, with dense, stout, upright branches and large pinnate leaves with 11-15 serrated, dull dark green leaflets. Clusters, up to 12cm across, of creamy-white flowers with a musky scent appear in late spring or early summer and are followed by heavy clusters of dark sealing-wax-red berries, each 1cm across, in late summer and early autumn
GenusDescription: Sorbus can be deciduous trees or shrubs with simple or pinnate leaves and clusters of small white or pink flowers, followed by white, yellow, pink, red or brown berries; some have fine autumn colour
ImageCopyRight: [Dorling Kindersley Ltd], [Dorling Kindersley Ltd], [Dorling Kindersley Ltd]
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, blister mites, scale insects, glasshouse red spider mite and sawflies
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings, treated with hormone rooting powder and rooted in a closed case with bottom heat or under mist in spring and early summer, by budding in summer, or by grafting in summer or winter. Although not all cuttings will root readily, in general, plants grown on their own roots produce better specimens
Pruning: No pruning required / Pruning group 1
Toxicity: Fruit is for ornamental purposes only.  Ingestion may cause mild stomach upset. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling

Cultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in full sun. Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter or early spring, and for best flowering apply a general rose or shrub fertiliser in early spring and again in early summer. See rose cultivation
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to rose black spot, rose rust, replant disease, rose dieback, and rose powdery mildews and sometimes honey fungus . May also be susceptible to disorders rose blindness and flower balling
EntityDescription: Vigorous and robust shrub rose about 2.5m tall, with a bushy spreading habit and mid-green leathery leaves. Very free-flowering and very fragrant, loosely semi-double, deep rose pink blooms, dappled red open from pointed buds, repeat-flowering through summer into autumn; suitable as a short climber
GenusDescription: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
HortGroupDescription: Shrub roses are large shrubs with usually thorny stems bearing large leaves and fragrant, single to double flowers in clusters in summer, and usually also in autumn
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly, rose slugworm sawfly and rose leaf-rolling sawfly. Deer and rabbits can cause damage
Propagation: Propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn, softwood cuttings (under glass) in spring or summer or by chip budding in summer
Pruning: See pruning group 20 (shrub roses); or can be trained as a short climber see pruning group 17 (climbing roses)

AutoCompleteField: Schizanthus grahamii|Graham's butterfly orchid|notched fringe flower
Cultivation: In cool temperate regions, grow outside in summer in containers or in a sheltered sunny border in light, fertile, well-drained soil, or in a conservatory or cool greenhouse (ventilate when temperatures rise above 7-10°C) in a coarsely draining, medium-fertility, loam-based mix, in full light with shade from hot sun or in bright filtered light; water sparingly in winter and plentifully when in full growth but without overwatering, and apply a dilute high-potash liquid fertilizer every two weeks; unlike other Schizanthus, S. grahamii is better grown on without pinching out
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to wilts, leafy gall, powdery mildews, crown, foot and root rots, and virus diseases such as tomato spotted wilt but generally disease-free
EntityDescription: S. grahamii is an upright annual 30-80cm high, with sticky, hairy stems, very finely divided leaves up to 8cm long, and in summer flowers to 3.5cm across which may vary in colour from pink to violet and purple, occasionally tinged orange, and deep yellow on the central lobe of the upper lip, followed by an ellipsoid capsule 10-12mm long
GenusDescription: Schizanthus are showly annuals with pinnately dissected leaves and terminal clusters of orchid-like, 2-lipped flowers in a wide range of colours and often with a contrasting eye, from spring to autumn
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids but generally pest-free
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown at 13-16°C in mid-spring for plants flowering in summer, or in late summer for plants grown for winter flowering under glass, and pot on regularly so that plants are in their final pots by late autumn
Pruning: No pruning required, but good as cut flowers

Cultivation: Grow in very well-drained but moist fertile soil in partial shade.  Position crowns above soil level level and surround with small stones
DiseaseResistance: Generally disease free
EntityDescription: a small, long-lived deciduous fern 20-30cm in height, with softly hairy, simply pinnate light green fronds, the pinnae slightly sickle-shaped
GenusDescription: Woodsia are small, tufted deciduous ferns with pinnate or 2-pinnate fronds, and are well-suited to a rock garden
PestResistance: Generally pest-free
Propagation: Propagate by spores or by division when dormant
Pruning: No pruning required

Cultivation: Can be grown outdoors in moist, fertile soil. Plant the base of the stem 5cm below the soil surface and provide a deep winter mulch and shelter from cold drying winds. See hardy fuchsia cultivation for further information
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to fuchsia rust, grey moulds and honey fungus (rarely)
EntityDescription: A compact, deciduous, bushy shrub to around 45cm tall and wide with dark green foliage. Single flowers are borne from summer into autumn and comprise green-tipped, pale pink sepals surrounding a white corolla veined with pink
GenusDescription: Fuchsia can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs or trees, rarely perennials, with opposite or whorled leaves and usually pendent flowers with conspicuous tubular calyx, 4 spreading sepals and 4 erect petals
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, fuchsia gall mite, capsid bug and vine weevil
Propagation: Propagate by softwood or semi-hardwood cuttings
Pruning: Pruning group 6

Cultivation: This cultivar is perfect for planting at sunny pond margins and boggy conditions. Plant in deep, moist to wet, humus-rich acidic soil. Will not tolerate dying out
DiseaseResistance: Generally disease free
EntityDescription: 'Mysterious Monique' is a robust, clump-forming perennial to 80cm tall with arching, narrow leaves and branched stems bearing several deep purple-blue flowers with white-yellow stripes and veining in summer
GenusDescription: Iris may be rhizomatous or bulbous perennials, with narrow leaves and erect stems bearing flowers with 3 large spreading or pendent fall petals, alternating with 3 erect, often smaller, standard petals, in late winter, spring or early summer
PestResistance: Susceptible to slugs, snails and thrips
Propagation: Propagate by division of rhizomes in autumn
Pruning: Remove any dying foliage in autumn; old flower stems can be cut down after flowering
Toxicity: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort. Wear gloves and wash hands after handling

Cultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in full sun or part shade; a good pillar rose, suited to a north-facing situation. Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter or early spring, and for best flowering apply a general rose or shrub fertiliser in early spring and again in early summer. See rose cultivation
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to rose black spot, rose rust, replant disease, rose dieback, and rose powdery mildew. May also be susceptible to disorders rose blindness and flower balling and sometimes honey fungus
EntityDescription: Robust, healthy climbing rose to 3.6m tall, a sport of R. 'Leverkusen' with glossy, pale green, serrated leaves and fragrant, double blooms of mid-pink to salmon, almost continously in flower through summer and into autumn. Can be grown as a large shrub with some support
GenusDescription: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
HortGroupDescription: Climbing roses are vigorous shrubs with thorny stems and large, solitary or clustered, often fragrant, usually remontant flowers
PestResistance: May be susceptible to aphids, rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly, rose slugworm sawfly and rose leaf-rolling sawfly. Deer and rabbits can cause damage
Propagation: For home use, propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn, softwood cuttings (under glass) in spring or summer or by chip budding in summer
Pruning: See pruning group 17 (climbing roses)

Cultivation: Grow in poor to moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun. Clumps tend to die out in the middle, so ideally divide every three years. Further ornamental grasses cultivation advice
DiseaseResistance: May be susceptible to a rust
EntityDescription: Forms small evergreen cushions to 30cm tall, of very fine bright blue leaves, becoming greener in winter. From late spring to summer it bears narrow, bristly blue-green flower plumes that turn golden-brown
GenusDescription: Festuca can be herbaceous or evergreen, rhizomatous grasses with linear, often strikingly coloured, leaves, and dense or lax panicles of brownish flowers in summer
PestResistance: Generally pest-free
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame in spring or by division in spring
Pruning: Comb out dead foliage and trim damaged parts of older leaves in spring

Cultivation: Plant bulbs in autumn, at least 10cm deep, in fertile, humus-rich, well-drained soil that does not dry out, in light dappled or partial shade, for example in a woodland garden, and mulch each year with leafmould; keep bulbs slightly damp during storage and before planting. See bulb cultivation
DiseaseResistance: Generally disease-free but may be affected by grey moulds and rust diseases
EntityDescription: 'Knightshayes Pink' is a bulbous herbaceous perennial up to 35cm high with elliptic, wavy-edged, deep green leaves, mottled with maroon, which die down in summer, and pink flowers with white bases dotted with yellow, and yellow anthers, in spring
GenusDescription: Erythronium are bulbous perennials with paired, ovate or broadly elliptic leaves, and leafless stems bearing one or more nodding, star-shaped flowers with recurved petals
PestResistance: May be affected by slugs
Propagation: Propagate by division of established clumps after flowering; re-plant immediately to make sure the bulbs do not dry out
Pruning: No pruning required
